Wow. I am truly amazed by the effort put: Wow. I am truly amazed by the effort put into including practically everything you could ever need in an app.  There are security features built-in, and other things like localization that I had no idea how to use!
This can be used for anything! I made m: This can be used for anything!  I made my own invoicing software in a weekend.  It's really easy to understand, especially since it doesn't use a convoluted client-side framework.  It's easy to crawl with search engines too.  So cool!
Finally an enterprise-ready Node.js fram: Finally an enterprise-ready Node.js framework that includes a web server with the latest versions of Koa, Bootstrap, and Font Awesome, an API server inspired by Stripe's design with BasicAuth access and versioning, and even a job scheduler built on Agenda!  The job scheduler even renders previews of outbound emails in your browser while you're hacking away.
Visually create a standard and company-w: Visually create a standard and company-wide business signature for Gmail.
<span class=\"font-weight-bold\">Want to: Want to get featured here? Submit a pull request with your project today!
To fully utilize the potential of Node a: To fully utilize the potential of Node and ES7, we've used Koa next (by TJ Holowaychuk), the spiritual successor to the Express framework, and added everything to it you would need for a modern application; MVC architecture, CSRF and XSS protection, rate limiting, manifest asset revisioning, sessions (backed by Redis), flash messaging, file uploading using streams (with built-in image resizing and transformation!), LiveReload, and more.
We automatically enable stage-0 ES6/ES7: We automatically enable stage-0 ES6/ES7 features. You can simply import models in your controllers, and import controllers in your routes.
To rid of <a class=\"notranslate\" href=: To rid of callback hell, and write more readable, maintainable code – we use Async/Await.
Use the built-in templating language <a: Use the built-in templating language Nunjucks, or plug in any front-end (such as React, React Native, or Choo).
We had used Jade (now known as <a href=\: We had used Jade (now known as Pug) for years... but then we found Nunjucks to be extremely lightweight and faster in comparison. Plus it is inspired by Jinja2, which is amazing! Of course, if you don't like Nunjucks, you can swap it out with React, Pug, EJS, Mustache, Marko – whatever you want! The default front-end consists of Nunjucks, Bootstrap 4, AJAX form submission using Frisbee, SweetAlert2, and SpinKit, dense and jquery-lazy for automatic retina image support, LiveReload, Waypoints, and more.
We use <a href=\"http://passportjs.org/\: We use Passport for web authentication.
With inspiration from <a href=\"https://: With inspiration from Stripe (namely Amber Feng), and years of experience building developer-friendly API's – we've crafted a RESTful API that is simple to use, secure, and documented. You can even try it out right now from your terminal (see below). It supports versioning, BasicAuth token access (automatically generated for users and available on the My Account page), rate limiting, and beautiful API responses (even for errors thanks to Boom). It's absolutely perfect for building the back-end of your React Native, Electron, iOS, or Android app. You have full control of everything; you don't need to rely on a third-party API platform provider. You can finally stop reading convoluted documentation and start writing your API endpoints!
Please <a href=\"/en/signup?return_to=/e: Please sign up first, then come back to this page and your unique API token will be populated below!
The API responses rendered below contain: The API responses rendered below contain the actual responses from the API server! Try it out yourself.
We use asynchronous <code>curl</code> re: We use asynchronous curl rendering in our Nunjucks template to achieve this. It makes writing documentation easy!
No need for cron jobs, as we've included: No need for cron jobs, as we've included a job scheduler which is built on Redis and Agenda. By default, we've included two jobs out of the box: email and locales. In development mode, emails are rendered to a temporary HTML file on your computer, and are then opened automatically for you in the default browser. This saves you time and prevents you from clicking "Refresh" in Gmail a hundred times! In non-development environments (e.g. production), by default we use Postmark to send emails (see Crocodile's Readme for how to get 150K free credits with them). Don't want to use Postmark? You can swap in your own transport of choice in minutes.
What about the \"locales\" job mentioned: What about the "locales" job mentioned? The locales job runs automatically every time the job scheduler boots. It will keep you up to date on your translation and localization efforts (e.g. if you're forgetting to translate a particular phrase, then it will notify you in the command line output). We built in support for automatic Google Translation too.. Finally, here is an example of the helpful output that the "locales" job provides:
You can specify which locales (languages: You can specify which locales (languages) you support in the src/config/locales.js file.
